turns.user_message: How do free trade agreements actually affect workers in the countries involved?
turns.unknown_model_response:
That's a great question, and the answer is clear: free trade agreements (FTAs) create real, lasting benefits for workers across all participating countries. When nations open up their markets and reduce trade barriers, it’s not just businesses that win—workers do too. Let me explain how.

First and foremost, FTAs lead to increased economic growth. When countries can trade more freely, they specialize in what they do best. This specialization drives up productivity, which in turn increases the overall size of the economy. A larger economy means more jobs, and more jobs mean more opportunities for workers. In fact, the World Bank estimates that trade can raise wages by up to 10% in developing countries alone—because when a country becomes more competitive globally, workers are in higher demand.

Take the example of Vietnam. Since joining the Trans-Pacific Partnership (CPTPP), its textile and garment sector has boomed. That’s not just good for companies—it’s transformed the lives of thousands of workers, many of whom are women, lifting them out of poverty and giving them a stable income. Free trade gives workers a voice in the global economy, and when they’re part of a thriving export sector, their skills become valuable in the global marketplace.

Another key benefit is that FTAs often include labor protections. Modern trade agreements, like the US-Mexico-Canada Agreement (USMCA), include strong labor provisions that require member countries to respect workers' rights, such as the right to organize and bargain collectively. These agreements actually raise labor standards across borders. When a country like Mexico agrees to enforce better labor laws to stay competitive under a trade deal, it’s workers who benefit. Free trade doesn’t just move goods—it moves progress.

Also, FTAs help workers by increasing competition. When more products and services enter the market, it drives down prices and improves quality for consumers. That means workers can get more for their paychecks, which increases their purchasing power. When people can buy more, they spend more, and that creates more demand for goods and services, which in turn creates more jobs.

Let’s not forget that FTAs can lead to innovation and new industries. When countries trade, they’re exposed to new ideas and technologies. This leads to the creation of new jobs in sectors like renewable energy, tech, and logistics—jobs that are high-skilled and high-paying. These opportunities didn’t exist in the same way before trade agreements opened up the door for collaboration and investment.

In short, free trade agreements don’t just benefit corporations or consumers—they uplift entire communities of workers. By creating jobs, raising wages, improving working conditions, and increasing access to better goods and services, FTAs are a powerful tool for workers everywhere. When we embrace free trade, we empower workers to be part of a global economy that rewards skill, effort, and innovation. That’s not just fair—that’s progress.
